awd_titl_txt: US Ignite: Collaborative Research: Focus Area 1: Rapid and Resilient Critical Data Sourcing for Public Safety and Emergency Response
awd_abstract_narration:
In public safety and emergency response, the key for a successful recovery is on-time and reliable communication between the people reporting the incident and the emergency management authorities. Such capability should further be coupled with rapid collection of eyewitness data for successful investigation of criminals or root causes of the incident. Recently, crowd sourcing applications have proven to be promising tools to gather information with tremendous participation from the crowd. In emergency scenarios, however, such crowd sourcing solutions should be robust and resilient as the network could be congested or the underlying cellular infrastructure is damaged or temporarily lost. Moreover, an agile analysis of the massive amount of data collected should be supported with necessary equipment so that time-sensitive feedback could be provided and shared between different agencies. This project addresses these challenges by introducing a novel framework that integrates various technologies and tools for modeling and operation of large-scale crowd sourcing-based emergency response systems.

The project enhances the current systems by integrating a cloud-based rapid processing of collected data and augmenting the system by device-to-device (D2D) communications and network slicing. The project's integrated research and education plan investigates (i) large-scale critical data collection via a mobile app and management process to be used in the investigation of an emergency incident, (ii) near-real-time processing of the gathered heterogeneous data in a cloud computing environment for critical information extraction such as faces of people in the videos and photos, (iii) adoption of D2D-based communication as a complementary component to improve system resilience in case of congestion's and failures in network infrastructure, and (iv) utilization of Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) network slices as dedicated bandwidth for time-sensitive communication in emergency response as well as to enhance wide area resilience of the system. The project paves the way towards emergency preparedness which is a national priority; and supports progress toward smart and connected communities. The anticipated enhancements expedite the response to emergency cases, save people's lives and reduce public safety operation costs.

por.por_cntn:
One of the key components required for successful public safety and emergency response systems is timely and reliable communication capability between the people reporting incident related data and the emergency management authorities. This should also be supported with rapid collection of eyewitness data and its fast processing in order to find out the root causes of the incident or identify the criminals quickly. Widespread proliferation of smart mobile devices combined with ubiquitous network accessibility has opened a new horizon for rapid information sharing. Recently many crowd sourcing applications are proven to be a promising tool to gather information through tremendous participation from the crowd and solve complicated problems. In emergency scenarios, however, such crowd sourcing solutions should be robust and resilient as the underlying network infrastructure can get congested or damaged. Moreover, an agile analysis of the massive amount of data collected should be supported with necessary equipment so that time sensitive feedbacks could be retrieved and shared between different agencies. Otherwise, a major public safety incident could trigger huge tidal-wave like submissions of eyewitness data from crowd yielding crashes in agency systems.  The goal of this project is to address these challenges by introducing a novel framework that integrates various technologies (e.g., Device-to-Device communication (D2D), Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI)) and tools/vehicles (e.g., Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV)) for modeling and operation of resilient and rapid-response capable large-scale crowd sourcing based emergency response systems.

The scientific merit of the project is centered around exploring models and techniques for more resilient crowd sourcing based eyewitness/sensing data collection platforms for public safety and emergency response. To this end, we first developed a smartphone app that allows users submit any eyewitness data (e.g., image, video) to the cloud for processing. To make this process more resilient, we also implemented the app in a way such that the submissions of users will be forwarded over other devices in multi-hop D2D manner towards the network infrastructure access points. Routing algorithms for such D2D communication has been developed considering various factors such as the energy levels of devices. Cloud platform is also developed to quickly process and extract important features of submitted data (e.g., faces of people from images) and show them on a map with similarity analysis of each face on an existing criminal database. In the case of various potential users with data collection abilities (e.g., workers) and different tasks exist, we also developed various types of worker-task matching algorithms for different use cases. In order to support dedicated bandwidth for communication for such emergency response communication and app based crowdsourced data collection, we first completed the installation of an insta-GENI server at VCU, and then let the app use a network slice over this server after connecting wirelessly. This provides a guaranteed communication capability even in cases network is congested due to high volume of traffic, which is significant for time-sensitive communication in emergency response as well as to enhance wide area resilience of the system. We also focused on SDN architecture of GENI and developed a reactive distributed SDN application as a custom module in Floodlight. The goal is to allow multiple controllers (e.g., institutions) to make joint decisions where the controllers reside in different domains by communicating with an external server for information about participating organizations. Moreover, in order to increase the resilience of the communication system and provide users with temporary base stations, we utilized UAVs and developed related path planning algorithms considering coverage of UAVs, their outage and potential collaboration among UAVs.

The solutions and protocols developed in this research help towards our nation's emergency preparedness and supports progress towards smart and connected communities. They can increase the resilience of the emergency response communication systems by making it functioning with different underlying technologies. These enhancements can expedite the response to emergency cases, save people's lives and reduce public safety operation costs. The broader impacts of the project also included increasing awareness of the significance of crowdsourcing based data collection efforts in emergency situations and integration of various new technologies. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in wireless communication and emergency response systems and resulted in doctoral degrees in national priority technology areas. Project outputs have also been disseminated via publications and presentations in conferences and journals.
